title: Basketball Scores: Surprising Results
question_text:
Suppose Jane is interested in the total number of points scored in Division I NCAA college basketball games. She takes a look at several years of data and finds this distribution is approximately normal with a mean of $154\text{ points}$ and a standard deviation of $9\text{ points}$.
Would it be surprising to find a game where the total number of points scored is over $185$?

choices.text: Yes, as the probability of this happening is between $5\%$ and $10\%$
Yes, as the probability of this happening is between $1\%$ and $5\%$
Yes, as the probability of this happening is less than $1\%$
No, as the probability of this happening is between $10\%$ and $30\%$
No, as the probability of this happening is more than $30\%$

solution:
Find the $z$-score that represents a score that adds to up $185$ by plugging in the mean and standard deviation to the standard score equation:

$$\dfrac{(185-154)}{9} = 3.44$$

Use the standard normal table to find,

$$P(z>3.44) = 1-0.9997 = 0.0003$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
